profileDesc.creation: Written by an anonymous female poet. One possible author of the text is Anne Finch (née Kingsmill), Countess of Wilchilsea (1661-1720). Six other poems in Miscellanea Sacra (1696) have been attributed to Finch, and “There's no disturbance in the Heavens above” shares the themes of enduring hardship and rejecting worldly pleasure that are found in several of her religious poems.
Set to music by John Jackson.
Musical setting appears in the devotional song collection Harmonia Sacra, compiled and published by Henry Playford in 1688.

body.head: The Words by a Young Lady.

lg.l: THere's no disturbance in the Heavens above
And heavenly Souls do nothing else but Love
No Anger, no Remorse, no Discontent
Can seize a Soul that's truly Innocent
And aims at nought, but that she may combine
With all she finds, like to her self, Divine
And seeing Things in such Confusion hurl'd
Does not contend with, but despise the World.
